The use of the word 'notify' would seem to assume no special need to obtain the authorisation or permission of the management of the Sheraton Hotel to have this violent, illegal and dangerous game played on its premises to the physical detriment of those premises and the overall detriment of the business. That is a matter which I hope the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) will clarify later in this debate, as I know he will do. I feel really left up in the air by the words relating to disciplinary action where it is stated:

While His Honour touches on the question of disciplinary or other action for those involved in the exercise, he has not made recommendations as to what disciplinary or other action, if any, should be taken. Those questions have been left for the responsible authorities to resolve.

I believe it would be useful for the Senate to know in due course just who the responsible authorities are and what action they take. It is vital to the community interest that this issue is followed up and resolved and the resolution made public. I think it is also vital for the people who work for ASIS that that should happen. If a degree of blame is to be attached to this matter I would say that it would be at least partially a very messy system under which ASIS operates. It is the business of the Government to see that this messy system is not perpetuated. But while it is one can hardly blame people if they take advantage of it or think that they can operate under guidelines that are not sufficiently strict. I will turn now to Mr Justice Hope's Report on the Sheraton Hotel Incident. On page 2, paragraph 1.7 of the report it is stated:

It was intended to conduct the exercise without publicity and without involving persons other than those directly taking part. In the event, members of the public did become involved and it was publicly revealed that the trainees had been carrying weapons, had threatened members of the public with them and had forced an entry into a room of the hotel causing damage to the hotel.

It seems a very naive assumption on the part of those concerned that an operation of that kind could actually be carried out at a major hotel in one of our major cities without rocking the boat very considerably indeed, as of course , was the case. We are also concerned about the carrying of weapons and the nature of those weapons. In this situation one would have thought that if this were merely a mock-up, a situation where indeed the later injections of the so- called security guards were simulated, there really would have been no need to be waving weapons around. A description of the weapons is contained on page 7 of Mr Justice Hope's report which states:
The list of equipment included four Heckler and Koch submachine guns, two of them silenced, and six Browning 9 mm automatic pistols.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were they loaded?
—We do not know whether they were loaded. That is an interesting point of Senator Chipp's. There is no statement that I can find on that.
—Yes, they were loaded.
—I gather from the interjection by Senator Lewis that they were loaded.
—They were loaded with plastic bullets.
—Thank you. That is a matter which the Attorney-General may like to take up later. The presence of any kind of loaded firearms in a public situation of that kind--
—They were loaded with plastic blanks.

—Of course, that information alters the situation substantially. Nevertheless there is no way that people terrorised with the firearms would know that. Again even weapons which are believed to be loaded with blanks are frequently known not to be. In fact, I think that such a situation might be even more dangerous. Perhaps one of those guns could even have been fired on the understanding that it was loaded with blanks even though it was not. That situation has occurred tragically many times. Cogent to this point we have a description on page 14 of Mr Justice Hope's report-a point which I think ought to be recorded in Hansard-of just how the weapons were actually used. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the team members lowered his submachine gun and pointed it at the Hotel Manager. A trainee held his hand gun in the air so that it could be seen. Seeking a way out of the hotel, the team advanced into the kitchen with some hotel staff, including the Manager, retreating before them. There is a conflict of evidence about whether guns were pointed at hotel staff in the kitchen. Hotel staff maintain that submachine guns were pointed directly at them, and that a hand gun was waved about. The trainees contend that the submachine guns were held across their chests and that one hand gun was held up, but not pointed at anyone.
I think a relevant point concerning the question of liquor is made on page 55 of the report. It states:
Although John--
John was the hostage who was to be rescued from the hotel room-
and the two 'foreign intelligence officers' had consumed about $70 worth of liquor over the 3 day duration of their stay in the hotel, this was not regarded by hotel management as excessive.
I will leave that point without further comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at those prices.

—Senator Chipp makes an excellent point. One would want to know the prices of the liquor to see how far the $70 went. Nevertheless I think if there is any evidence that there was an unreasonable amount of liquor consumed in that time that is something that ought not to have happened. I mentioned the recommendations made on page 69 of the report. Mr Justice Hope recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) no ASIS officer, trainee or agent be permitted to carry any type of firearms in any public place in Australia.
I hope that the Attorney-General will comment at this stage giving us his view and that of the Government on these recommendations if he can. The recommendations continued:

(b) no ASIS exercise, conducted outside ASIS' own facilities, which may attract the attention of the police or members of the public, should be undertaken without clearance from the police, from the local military district . . . and from any private citizen whose property may be affected or who may become in some way involved in the exercise;
(c) no exercise should be conducted by ASIS which would harm or alarm members of the public, and ASIS trainees should be so instructed.
I think those are the most important recommendations except for recommendation ( f) which states:
(f) ASIS training manuals should be amended or completed as a matter of urgency to incorporate the above recommendations;
Perhaps that is the most important recommendation of all.

The Sheraton incident has revealed the necessity of not going in for this cloak and dagger activity as if it were some kind of game, as if it were an operation to be done light-heartedly. It is a very serious matter and should be subject to the most stringent planning and supervision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to say a few words about the report on the Sheraton Hotel incident. I open my remarks by congratulating His Honour Mr Justice Hope for the balance and perspective which I believe he has shown in the report. I also congratulate the Government for making the report available to the Parliament and to the public because there is no doubt this matter has caused grave concern right throughout the nation. The availability of the report has, to those of us who have read it, at least allayed some of that concern. The pity of it all of course is that this fiasco-it can be described as nothing else --
—I have a better word for it.
—Senator Chipp has a better word.
—But I am not prepared to use it.

—No doubt Senator Chipp will tell me later. The pity of the matter is that it has tended to bring Australia's Secret Intelligence Service and intelligence organisations into discredit. Scorn has been heaped on the Service. I have no doubt that officers serving in our security forces are most concerned that their reputations have been tarnished as a result of this nonsense. I think that is a great pity because notwithstanding its size Australia is a small nation. Small nations have shown time after time that really the only way to survive in this world is to have excellent intelligence information. Israel has shown the enormous benefits of its intelligence organisation. Any analysis of what went on prior to the Second World War will show the folly of allowing one's intelligence organisations to be run on small budgets and for people in important positions, such as Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers, not to take notice of intelligence organisation reports. I draw attention to Lord Carrington 's resignation over the Faulkland Islands crisis. Clearly he was not taking proper notice of the reports and material which was being supplied to him and he recognised this. It is a great pity that our organisation has perhaps been tarnished by this nonsense which, on any analysis as Mr Justice Hope's report reveals, was probably unnecessary at that stage and was planned too early bearing in mind the concept of what it was all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I will talk about the concept. Mr Justice Hope says that the primary function of ASIS is the collection of foreign intelligence. He then pointed out the ASIS is also required in a minor way to maintain a covert action-a secret action- capability. This has been the case since August 1982. One of the minor projects of ASIS is to develop this covert action capability. I am not sure of the reasons, but I think I can understand why there is a need for a covert action responsibility. However this would not be taken in Australia. I am sure very few people realise that the people involved in this action were not permanent officers of ASIS; they were civilians, part time agents, who came together for periods of training. At other times they pursued their normal civilian occupations. I take it that when the need arose they would be called together. That need was clearly to be seen as something which would take place only in a dire emergency, perhaps in war time or if some four overseas officials were being held hostage. Let me state Mr Justice Hope's recommendation in which he sums it up:
I have concluded that the exercise was poorly planned, poorly supervised, and poorly run.

That is undoubtedly a conclusion which one must draw from any analysis of the report and the nature of what went wrong. Although I recognise that the officers who conducted this exercise must be held responsible for their own actions, I heard the Premier of Victoria, Mr John Cain, pleading the Nuremberg defence, in other words, the officers were ordered to do this. One must have great sympathy for them and little sympathy for the person who organised the exercise. It was a surveillance exercise right up until 29 November when John-the person who was being watched-was in the hotel. At 4 o'clock on the afternoon of 29 November the team leader was informed that the team was now required to rescue this person using the minimum force necessary. What a lot of nonsense! What force? some force would have had to take place at that stage if there was to be any sort of entry into the building. Were they going to use grappling hooks and come down the wall, break window or smash down a door? Force would have had to be used unless the so-called foreign agents who were guarding John were prepared to let these people in through the door. When an attempt was made to enter the door as a waiter, the people guarding John refused to open it. The moment they refused to open the door, of course, force was inevitable. The whole thing was a disaster from thereon in. Mr Justice Hope, quite rightly, condemned it.

Some of the points which Mr Justice Hope raised which cause me some concern are his future recommendations on how such an exercise should be carried out in the future. I am running short of time and I do not want to delay the Senate, but it seems that on the basis of his recommendations it will be practically impossible for ASIS ever to conduct such an exercise again except perhaps on Commonwealth- owned property. If those recommendations have been adopted by the Government the result will be that Senator Mason's concerns will not bother us because the incident will never happen again in Australia. Therefore we will not have to bother about this sort of thing. Mr Justice Hope raised the question of ministerial responsibility. At paragraph 3.8 he stated:

It is convenient to deal with the question of ministerial responsibility for the incident at this point. There was no suggestion that the Minister responsible for ASIS, Mr Hayden, should have been informed of the kind of special operations training which was being undertaken in November, nor of the specific exercise which concluded at the Sheraton Hotel. The Acting Director- General had no duty to inform the Minister of the training proposed. For his part, the Minister had no duty to inquire into what specific training was proposed or proceeding in the special operations field. Having given his general approval for the projects ASIS had commenced, the Minister was entitled to believe that the Acting Director-General would ensure that special operations activities were conducted legally, properly, and safely.

That seems to have been passed over the Parliament and been accepted. However, I wonder what would have been the result had this fiasco gone further astray? In my interjection to Senator Mason I drew attention to the possibility that perhaps a security officer at the hotel, a policeman, or the hotel manager may have responded to the waving of a pistol, submachine gun or other armaments, by firing a shot as a result of which one of the trainees may have been killed or wounded or even an innocent bystander may have been killed or wounded. What would have been the ministerial responsibility in that event? I raise this question because it seems to me, as a senator and member of this Commonwealth Parliament, that the situation in regard to ministerial responsibility has become very fluid. What concerns me is that Mr Justice Hope seems to have accepted the situation that a Minister is not responsible when he did not know what was happening in his Department and perhaps could not be expected to know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you remember the position you took on the bottom-of-the -harbour legislation last year?

—I have been reminded of an incident which occurred last year. I recall what Senator Gareth Evans said when he was in opposition. On 25 August 1982 at page 466 of Hansard he stated in relation to the former Attorney-General of this Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . even if he did not know, and even if . . . he could not be expected to have known what was going on, then he should offer to resign anyway, because of the magnitude of the disaster involved for the Australian nation as a result of his purported performance of his ministerial duties.
The only reason this matter is not being raised by all and sundry in this debate is that this fiasco turned out with no one being injured and only minor property damage.

This is an interim arrangement. A change to the allocation of broadcast times beween the Senate and the House of Representatives has yet to be agreed upon by the Committee. For the information of honourable senators, the interim arrangement means that, for next week, the Senate will be broadcast on Monday and Wednesday, and the House of Representatives on Tuesday and Thursday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen the report in today's Age which details the checks that that newspaper carried out before publication of the tapes and particularly the transcripts? Is he also aware that the Age had audio tests done on the tapes before it satisfied itself that the material was authentic? Does the Attorney-General stand by his view of Tuesday that the material is completely unauthenticated in the light of this detailed information . I ask, further, whether he still maintains that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the role of the Age newspaper in this whole affair has not been a very proud one . . .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen nothing in the Age this morning which leads me to vary that initial judgment. Of course it is the case, as the Age says, that checks have been done on a number of things that are checkable in the written material, the summaries and the transcripts-such things as the location of telephone numbers and of particular people at places they are said to be at the time that the purported conversations were recorded. I think that even Senator Durack, however, would appreciate that the status of the material is not advanced one iota by virtue of checks of that kind. ANSWER.PARA: As to the authenticity of the electronic tapes, I continue to repeat what I have said previously, that is, that there are grounds for believing that there are problems about the authenticity of the material in question. I note what Mr Wran said yesterday in the New South Wales Parliament in that respect. The material on which he drew in that answer was, in fact, also available to me and I can confirm the accuracy of that. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to his comments in the Senate last year to the effect that he was planning to inspect a number of solar and wind technologies on his overseas visit. Will the Minister advise the Senate whether he has drawn any conclusions from his inspections? If so, what are they?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The conclusion that I have drawn from the information given overseas is that, with isolated exceptions-one of which I shall detail later-and with present technology, the cost of either wind power or solar power is vastly in excess of that of the alternative supplies which are available for the overwhelming majority of Australia, that is, any part of Australia which has access to cheap coal. For example, in Denmark wind generated power is estimated to cost 4c per kilowatt hour. That is at the point of production, not the point of delivery. Sydkraft, in Sweden, manufacturers of wind generating machines, estimate a cost of between 3c and 4c per kilowatt hour with the improved machine that it intends to produce shortly. The cost with the existing machine is higher than that. The wind speeds at those locations are close to the best known average wind speeds at an Australian site.

ANSWER.PARA: Solar electricity is very much more expensive. Again, these figures come from the manufacturers of the equipment, so one would be surprised, to say the least, if the figures erred on the low side. The estimated cost of generating electricity at the McDonnell-Douglas thermal solar power plant at Bairstow, a 10 -megawatt power plant, is between 25c and 30c per kilowatt hour. The Arco photovoltaic plant, also in southern California, has an estimated cost of 60c per kilowatt hour.

So, while the wind generated electricity in raw costs is not within a factor of one, anyway, of the cost of coal generated electricity in most parts of Australia, the cost of solar power, be it thermal or photovoltaic, is higher than Australian generating costs by a factor of 10 or even 20. In both cases, of course, the supply of electricity is discontinuous-that is, electricity can be produced only when the wind is blowing, in the first instance, or when the sun is shining, in the second.

The major exception to that general conclusion is that, pending the production of relevant technical data, it may be possible that where a limited amount of wind generated electricity could be economic in Australia is in north-western Tasmania, where it is known that wind velocities are about eight metres per second. There is a possibility that there may be some locations where it is higher than eight metres per second and where any power produced would be fed into what is basically a hydro grid which can be turned on and off very quickly. In other words, for those periods when the wind is not blowing, instant or virtually instant power can be produced from other sources.

I also visited some impressive experimental work-I shall not go into any depth on this-which the Swedes are conducting at Stripa, an abandoned iron ore mine, experimental work relating to the ultimate disposal of highly active nuclear wastes. I shall not go into the details of that. Some of them are given in the report of the visit which has been prepared, and which I now table.

—I explained earlier today that I am not going to nurture and nourish further the exploratory adventures in which the Opposition is now engaging. Whatever the truth of the matter may ultimately prove to be-and we shall be a better position to judge that when we have had a report on the authenticity of the tape material-the fact of the matter, as I have constantly repeated, is that even if the material, both tape and transcript, is absolutely authentic, even if every single word recorded in those tapes and transcripts was actually said and is recorded accurately, nonetheless, at the end of the day, one would be left with the conclusions that I believe were quite properly produced by Mr Temby on his analysis of the law and supported as that was by the Solicitor-General's analysis of the law, which is that nothing in this material either established or pointed to any criminal misconduct on the part of the judge; nor did any of this material, if authentic, if accurately recorded, in any way relate to the judicial conduct of the judge. As such-and I repeat again what I have said earlier today and at numerous times previously-there is nothing in the material which could possible or justly give rise to consideration as to whether the judge may have been guilty of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution and as such, particularly given the manifest illegality and privacy invading character of this material, I do not propose to nourish further the Opposition's desire to make some sort of capital-it clearly knows not what-out of this matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —I had a conversation with him. The question simply did not arise as to whether the judge had any view as to whether the voice he was hearing-his own or someone else's-was his own. It is not a matter that I pursued with him and it is not a matter that I propose to pursue with the honourable senator now.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations seen the report in today's Australian Financial Review headed 'Australia has third worst work safety record says NSC'? It reports that according to recent assessments by the National Safety Council in New South Wales alone, 300 people die each year through industrial accidents and diseases and each year there are 145,000 accidents from which workers are incapacitated for more than three days. Will the Minister comment on these figures compared to the claims for the same figures being the Australia-wide figures for last year? Will the Minister agree that these figures are quite appalling and that any reduction in the number of industrial deaths and accidents would contribute to a considerable reduction in on-costs to industry and to increased productivity, apart from the great saving to human pain and misery? Will the Minister comment on the need for rapid implementation of the Government's occupational health and safety program and adequate industrial data collection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report in this morning's Australian Financial Review. Senator Crowley might be surprised to know that in those circumstances I have not discussed it with the Minister. On my recollection of the figures provided by Senator Crowley and which are apparently published in the Financial Review, they are consistent with the figures which were published last year and with the figures which have been published in Australia over many years in relation to industrial health and safety matters. I think those figures have been seen by all honourable senators from time to time, even in the worst years of industrial disputation in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I am making the point that the time lost in Australia through industrial accidents has always been enormously high compared with time lost through industrial disputation and a variety of other matters. It is a problem which has not ever been addressed adequately by governments. In that historical context, it is sad that the present Government is now giving major attention to these problems at a time when the nature of industrial activity is changing significantly both in terms of equipment used and so on and in terms of the technological upmarketing of industry which makes accidents and disease of this kind probably less likely. The honorable senator and other honourable senators will be aware of the Government's proposals in respect of the national commission and the priority which the Government is giving to this question. The two things are very much related. That is all I can say in answer to the honourable senator's question. TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Attorney-General agree that the Parliament has responsibilities in regard to the conduct of members of the judiciary? Will he arrange for the relevant Age tapes and transcripts to be tabled in the Senate in a form which would protect the identity of the individuals concerned to enable the Senate to make its own judgment about these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliament's responsibilities in relation to the conduct of the judiciary begin and end with Parliament's role in relation to section 72 (ii ) of the Constitution. There are excellent reasons for that, given the principle of the separation of powers which, particularly in a federation such as our own, as we are constantly being reminded by honourable senators on the other side, it is crucial to maintain.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition, motivated as it undoubtedly is at the moment by the kind of political adventurism I described before rather than anything which could be dignified as public spiritedness, is not advancing any legitimate cause but is simply trying to make something out of an issue which does not justify that kind of attention.

I repeat, as I have done twice already today, because it does not seem to have sunk in: Even on the worst case assumptions in the sense of fully accepting the authenticity of the material, both electronic and written, and even on the most complete acceptance of the accuracy of every last detail as transcribed and recorded in the Age and as might be read were this material to be tabled, the conclusion of two very distinguished Australian lawyers is that that is the relevant law. Those two Australians are the Director of Public Prosecutions designate and current President of the Law Council of Australia, who is respected by his peers and his inferiors all around the country, and the Solicitor-General, a man who was briefed regularly on all sorts of important cases by the Opposition when it was in government and whose integrity, independence and legal ability is unquestioned.

Mr Temby, who is highly experienced in applying the law to particular facts, has reached the conclusion that there is no conceivable foundation upon which this Parliament, or anybody applying the proper standards of misbehaviour which are referred to in section 72 of the Constitution, could come to the view either that there was anything here bearing upon or relating to this man's role in his judicial office or in any way establishing or pointing to criminal misconduct. Under those circumstances there is no question, as I have repeated twice already , of nurturing further the exploratory urges of this bereft Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note the Attorney-General's answer which is that our only responsibilities relate to section 72 of the Constitution. I remind the Attorney that, in his statement on Tuesday, he referred to his own intervention about the High Court of Australia in a very lengthy address which he gave in this place. I ask him: Was his attack on the High Court at that time related to his responsibilities under section 72, or was it related to his broader responsibilities as a member of this Senate to watch the public interest?

—I am very happy that Senator Chaney asked me that supplementary question because it is the case that that speech, which related to Sir Garfield Barwick, the affairs of his private company and the possible conflicts of interest in which he was involved, was very squarely directed to the judge's performance of his judicial office. What was squarely in issue in the Mundroola affair and in the matters that I drew to the attention of the Parliament were the potential conflicts of interest which arose from the fact that the Chief Justice, against all convention, had continued to maintain, over a long period, an active directorial role in a private land and investment company, which company in turn had shares in CSR Ltd, Brambles Security Group Ltd and Ampol Ltd, three major Australian companies which had been the subject of litigation on several occasions before that judge in the High Court, without that judge not only not disqualifying himself but also not even disclosing to the parties that he had that financial interest or indirect business interest. That was absolutely squarely related to the proper performance of judicial function. Had there been anything in this material which raised similar questions of bias or conflict of interest, had there been anything which in the view of Mr Temby had possibly given rise to that, then there would be no question but that that matter would have to be conceded by me to be squarely relevant to a potential application of section 72. I assure the Senate-I stand by this-that there is nothing in that material which justifies any such description. I do not propose to trail before the salacious eyes and ears of the Opposition and indeed the Australian public, as nurtured by an equally salacious Press in this instance, material which, at the most extreme assumptions about its authenticity and the most extreme assumptions about its accuracy, neither of which assumptions is accepted, is material which could give rise to an action of that kind. I hope I have made myself clear.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing uncertainty being created by the Government's proposal to introduce a resources rent tax.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that this matter of public importance could more accurately have been worded by referring to the discredited former resource rent tax proposals of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) because it is quite clear that the proposal he originally put forward has been severely deserted by the Government of which he is a member. He is left holding but one remnant of the garment that he held out to us in such attractive economic terms. The Opposition is concerned about the fact that the Government in this matter is giving rise to very great uncertainty. That is causing concern to an industry which is of great importance to Australia and an industry which affects the long term stability of our fuel supplies and our independence from that point of view. I do not know what aspect of the matter Senator Walsh will choose to address. But I hope that he will not try to argue that there has not been continuing uncertainty about the matter that he has in hand-the imposition of a resource rent tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Not very long ago he told Australia and the Parliament that he would impose a resource rent tax on coal and oil and that that tax would apply throughout the country and, of course, it would apply off-shore, where most of our oil resources are won. We now know that the Government has stepped back from the coal industry. Senator Walsh has indicated that he does not see that the Government could introduce the tax on-shore. He is now saying that he confidently expects a tax to be imposed from 1 July on off-shore oil and gas. But the certainty in all the public expressions which I have seen from the Minister does not seem to be shared by all of his colleagues. It certainly does not seem to be shared by the Premier of Western Australia. The other night, on one of the rare occasions when I was able to watch television, on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news I saw Labor Premier Burke speaking to an audience of New York businessmen, obviously trying to say things that would please them. I quote from the transcript of Mr Burke's remarks:

My quite frank view is that the tax is unlikely to be imposed as from July 1st. Although the announcement of its application has been made, I am sure that it is with much less joy that the National Government embraces the concept than it embraced it from the Opposition Benches.

I sometimes wonder whether Senator Walsh, who has been handed this thorny task, looks at the present Treasurer, Mr Keating, and thinks of him as the now discredited shadow Minister for Minerals and Energy for having run so hard with the proposition which has proved so difficult, if not impossible, to implement. But Premier Burke, a Labor Premier who shares the views of Labor and non-Labor Premiers alike about this tax, namely that it is a tax which should not be imposed, was expressing, perhaps, no more than a pious hope. I hope that Senator Walsh will be able to enlighten the Senate a little more about just what are the Government's present intentions. I certainly do not expect him to give us the sort of specific information that he has been promising and which he has been unable to deliver so far, which would tell us just what effect this tax will have on the industry.

I do not know whether Premier Burke was acting as an agent for the Hawke Government when he set out to ease the fears of his audience. But I must say that, from the looks on people's faces as they were shown on the television screen, they did not look too reassured. The same lack of reassurance is evident on the faces of the people who are responsible for the oil industry in Australia . There is dual uncertainty-uncertainty in the Government and uncertainty in the industry. I think there is still uncertainty in the Government about just what to do. I was very taken by a comment from someone who met Senator Walsh while he was overseas recently. He said: 'There is no doubt about Senator Walsh. He knows that he wants to do something, but I do not think he knows what it is'. I suspect, from the sort of information which Senator Walsh has been putting out, that that is a fairly accurate summary. He knows what he wants to do. He wants to put in a more rational tax, something which is profit based. He wants to put in something which will not deter investment. But he does not really know what to do. The attempts he has made to explain the matter-I welcome the fact that the Minister has put out some discussion papers and invited public comment-have still left very great areas of uncertainty. The fact is that the Government has backed and filled. Senator Walsh has backed and filled. The minerals to which the tax is to apply and the locations to which it is to apply have varied and that, of course, is of great concern to the Opposition and to Australia.

The second area of uncertainty I mention is in the industry itself. I will refer to some of the recent statements which have been made by industry sources which make it very clear what is the attitude of the oil and gas industry to what the Government has been proposing. As recently as 3 February APEA-the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd-issued a detailed statement in which it put its view that the tax was one which should not be imposed. I quote in part from the Press article reporting that statement:

The Federal Government's proposed resources rent tax was already seriously affecting investment in petroleum exploration and development, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd said yesterday.
The article continued:

Offshore drilling is expected to fall from 49 exploration wells last year to 32 this, . . . more offshore wells had been expected to be drilled in 1984, so the logical conclusion to be drawn from the 1984 survey was that the Government's proposal to apply the tax offshore initially was already causing investment caution.
Mr Orchison, on behalf of the Association, stated:
'Exploration programs are highly sensitive to changing circumstances such as the proposed resources rent tax-commitments to contractors at this stage are only 113 exploration wells'.

I do not want to go into all the figures which APEA has given. I know Senator Walsh is likely to point to the fact that quite a substantial number of wells have been drilled over recent years. However, I think Senator Walsh would also agree that over this current year and last year there has been a very significant decline in the amount of seismic work done. That of course is the forerunner to drilling. It is quite clear that there is a downturn in that area and it is quite clear that the industry is expecting a further downturn in drilling.

I have heard Senator Walsh in this place before saying that that is all very well but that that downturn is related to changing conditions in the oil industry world-wide. I do not wish to mask the fact that, since the world price of oil has stabilised and at times dropped in real terms and since demand has dropped and supply become readily available, of course interest in exploration has declined. That fact does not detract from the argument I am putting, rather it supplements and buttresses it. Of course it is in Australia's continuing national interest to maintain oil self-sufficiency. It does not matter what the immediate market conditions are. The fact is that Australia, with a current high degree of self-sufficiency, faces a significant decline in self-sufficiency. Australia faces the fact that this is not a particularly prospective area for oil exploration and that in the world there is always the risk of shortage because of the instability of many of the areas from which oil is taken. It must be in the national interest to maintain a high level of self-sufficiency. That means a high level of exploration.

If there are external economic factors working against the search for oil in Australia it ill becomes the Government to take steps that will buttress and further that trend. The more Senator Walsh points to external conditions as augmenting the decline in interest in exploration the more he argues against the sorts of changes that he is proposing, which clearly present a disincentive to the people engaged in this industry. I quote again from the APEA statement in which Mr Orchison, on behalf of the organisation, is reported as saying that he:
. . . believed the RRT was unsound and impractical. They feel there is little value in replacing the present tax arrangements for the petroleum exploration industry with a tax that is complex . . .
The present arrangements have encouraged exploration, so there is no point in giving away a system that works for one that may not work . . .
The shelving of the Government's RRT plans is essential to sustain exploration effort.

I am sure Senator Walsh is familiar with many other statements of people in the industry. I will mention only one other statement, that of The Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd, a major company with interests in this field. On a couple of occasions we have had spokesmen from that company pointing out that if there had been a resource rent tax when Jabiru was being considered BHP would have decided not to drill.

The Minister is entitled to say that he takes with a grain of salt the views of these people and that after all Senator Chaney is citing the views of people who will be affected by this tax. That is correct of course. I think it is abundantly clear that the people in this industry who are required to make investment decisions believe that the incentive for exploration will be diminished by what Senator Walsh is proposing. I think that is the reality faced by Senator Walsh and the Government. I do not believe there is any escaping that reality.

The problems of the tax have been perceived to be problems outside Australia. I have already mentioned that the Premier of Western Australia saw fit to deny the words of Senator Walsh and to suggest that in fact the tax would not be in place by 1 July. I draw the Minister's attention to the reference in Australian Business to the American mining magazine Engineering and Mining Journal which recently comprehensively reviewed the Australian mineral scene. It pointed out the anguish of the mining and exploration industries over resource tax initiatives by Canberra. I do not think there is any doubt that there is uncertainty. There has been continuing uncertainty in the mind of the Government and in the mind of the industry. It is the uncertainty in the minds of the people that make up this industry that is creating potential problems for Australia.

I believe that the premier and very heavy responsibility that Senator Walsh carries is to maintain an environment conducive to encouraging oil self- sufficiency in Australia. I do not believe that it is an easy task. I believe that in a government where there will be a very heavy scramble for revenue to enable it to meet the sorts of reductions in personal income tax that are no doubt needed as a pre-election sweetener the pressures on Senator Walsh and his Department will be heavy indeed. I think if he takes his duties seriously and in the national interest-I am sure he does-he will agree that one of his premier responsibilities, if not his premier responsibility, is to maintain a high exploration effort, thus maintaining the highest possible oil self-sufficiency in this country.

I have never accused the Minister of insincerity or of having a lack of a purely theoretical base for the propositions which he has advanced. I say that because I think he has tried to put the case in terms which are logical. He has talked of the need to lift non-profit related taxes because of their potentially deleterious effect. He has talked of imposing this new tax only above the ceiling which is required to bring about investment in this essential industry. I acknowledge that in that sense he has put forward arguments which take into account the sorts of concerns which I have expressed. I think it is now abundantly clear that there are very great problems with the theory he has put forward. Those problems arise both on a theoretical and a practical level.

I believe the first problem that the Minister cannot overcome is that relating to the ceiling point. The point at which the tax begins to apply is a judgment. Senator Walsh has to try to find a figure which is the figure at which people will be prepared to put money into this very risky industry. I think if a very careful analysis were done of the actual workings of companies it would be possible to divine that figure at a particular time. I ask Senator Walsh to concede that that calculation is a calculation of a moment. It is a calculation based on circumstances on a particular day in a particular month and in a particular year. The ceiling which he is pursuing is in fact a moving target. The sort of stable tax regime which he is recommending cannot meet the theoretical model for multiple projects and at the same time maintain the sort of stability he has talked about.

The second problem for Senator Walsh and the Government is that if they are going to go down the theoretical path outlined by Senator Walsh they have to base the cut-in point for the tax on the figure required to maintain investment rather than a particular revenue target. It seems quite clear from Senator Walsh 's recent statements that the Government has to tailor this tax with revenue targets in mind. Senator Walsh has begun to be quite explicit about that. Senator Walsh has said that we need to raise the same money out of old oil and that we need to raise additional money out of new oil, say an additional 10 per cent. Once he starts setting the threshold figures and the tax rates on the basis of some revenue target it seems to me that the theoretical attractiveness of this tax disappears because the threshold is being set not from the point of view of trying to make an inspired guess at the magic figure at which people will continue to invest but of making a rather more prosaic stab at the figure that will return 300, 400, 500, or whatever number, of hundreds of millions of dollars extra revenue is required.

Another problem for the Minister is that the figure is simply not going to be static and that varying conditions will prevail. The oil price situation of course is something which is very variable. There will be variable returns with this sort of resources rent tax approach of Senator Walsh. Again it is not a matter that will be of very great practical assistance to his Government. Of course the major obstacle and the obstacle which has already caused the Government and Senator Walsh to withdraw from a great deal of this area-that is, to withdraw as far as coal and on-shore oil is concerned-is that the model which he has constructed ignores the realities of the Federal system. On this occasion Senator Walsh cannot rail against Premier Bjelke-Petersen and say that it is all his and Premier Gray's fault and ascribe to them the demonic qualities that he likes to ascribe to non-Labor politicians because he faces the fact that his Labor colleagues from the States have the same low opinion of what he is trying to do as do the non-Labor Premiers around Australia.

We face the situation where the Government has made backdowns, where the Government has indicated that it will depart from the theoretical base that Senator Walsh outlined. The Government will have to pursue revenue targets and perhaps, most importantly, the economic logic that Senator Walsh sought to embrace will be totally absent from the fact that one will have one sort of tax regime on-shore and a different tax regime off-shore. That means, of course, that there will be a major distortion of the investment decisions which are made about oil exploration in Australia. I believe it is quite clear that it is not in the national interest for the Government to continue to pursue this mirage. I do not believe it is in the national interest, if the Government is to back down further, that that back down should be further postponed. I believe that the disquiet which is evident in the industry should be put to bed. If the honest reality is that this Government is determined to tax oil more, it ought to do so in a simpler manner which is more acceptable to the industry than to go through the hoops which Senator Walsh is at present trying to jump, to no good effect at all.

In what is a very limited time of debate on a very important subject, I simply close by saying to the Senate that I believe it is the primary task of Senator Walsh, his Department and his Government's activities in this area, that they maintain an exploration effort which will best possibly ensure Australia's self- sufficiency in liquid fuels. The Government cannot escape that primary obligation; it cannot escape that primary duty. The course which is being followed by Senator Walsh at the moment is not in the national interest because it cuts across that fundamental objective. I ask the Government to withdraw this proposal and to deal with the matter in a more sensible way which will avoid some of the problems which are currently being created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have agreed to limit my speech to 15 minutes so I probably will not have time to cover all the points that have been raised. Senator Chaney at the end of his speech and earlier seemed to be implying that the sole objective of an oil policy should be to maintain a level of exploration sufficient to maintain self- sufficiency. If that is his belief-if that was the belief of the previous Government-it begs this question. Why was there any tax at all, under the previous Government's policy, on new oil? Even on new oil the previous Government's policy imposed a 10 per cent ad valorem levy in certain circumstances, probably a 12 1/2 per cent ad valorem levy and company taxation. If the only objective which was worth pursuing was to maximise the exploration activity for new oil the previous Government should not have imposed any tax at all. I would welcome from subsequent speakers an explanation. What they would have to acknowledge, of course, ultimately is that it is a matter of judgment as to what tax regime is consistent with an optimum level of exploration activity and that is a matter of judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney has claimed that the Government has continually backed away from the proposal. He claimed, quite wrongly I believe, that I had said a tax would be applied on coal. I certainly do not remember ever saying that. If I did I would be obliged if Senator Chaney could refer me to it. What I have said on many occasions is that the two obvious candidates for the application of a rent tax are export quality coal and oil because they are two commodities in respect of which in many cases the economic rents are high. This is particularly so in the case of oil. I have always acknowledged that it was not feasible to introduce a rent tax on export quality coal unless the States co-operated. I have also acknowledged the possibility that they would not co-operate. Likewise I have always acknowledged the possibility that the States would not co-operate in the application of a rent tax on petroleum products on-shore where they have the primary taxing right. At least six months ago I publicly made statements to that effect. I said that if the States will not co-operate in respect of on- shore oil the Commonwealth, reluctantly, will be forced to proceed off-shore only. That will still achieve some 90 per cent of our objective because 90 per cent of petroleum products are produced off-shore. That is a ratio which is likely to be maintained.

The reason why the Australian Labor Party, way back in 1977, initially adopted this policy-I am sure Senator Chaney is at least broadly aware of it-is that it is a superior tax. A rent tax, in terms of economic efficiency, is a superior tax to any other form of taxation. The major technical reason for that is that a properly structured rent tax imposes no tax on a marginal project and no tax on the marginal production or output of an above marginal project. It also improves the cash flow of a project in its early years as against any other alternative. Therefore it has been in the Labor Party platform since 1977. It was canvassed heavily by my predecessor the present Treasurer, Mr Keating. I will quote just a couple of the many statements Mr Keating made on the subject. On 25 March 1980 in a speech to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association he said:

It would be the intention of the Labor Party in office to scrap the existing levy system and replace it with a resource rent tax. This would mean that all existing Bass Strait production would receive a uniform price and be subject to a resource rent tax . . .
In the same speech he said:

A Labor Government would price new oil . . . at the full import parity price, but this oil would be subject to a resource rent tax. A resource rent tax therefore would operate on all Australian oil production, both old and new.
On 29 April 1982, in the House of Representatives, Mr Keating stated:

. . . the Opposition has supported a resources rent tax which is a much fairer, more equitable and more stable form of taxation which does not discriminate against marginal production or from the draining of reservoirs and which would, of course, be non-distortionary and produce the right kinds of production decisions which we will not see produced from the existing levy system.

One point I would like to add in the limited time available to me is that the existing system imposes nothing more than corporate tax and the ad valorem levy on new oil and maximum rates as a primary tax, a levy, of up to 87 per cent on old oil. From those facts it is obvious that the distinction between new and old oil is a very important one and one which cannot in all circumstances be made with certainty. Indeed the possibility of new geological evidence emerging which could lead to informed geological opinion changing on whether a particular pool of oil should be classified as new or old is present. At the margin, even without new geological evidence coming forward, it becomes a matter of judgment rather than a matter of certainty. There are many other factors which could be mentioned but I do not have the time to do it.

Since the election of the present Government, in addition to repeating the justifications for the tax which my predecessor had stated over many years, assurances were given in conformity with the general policy of this Government that there would be wide consultation with the industry and other interested parties. In 1977 the Fraser Government considered the application of a resources rent tax and publicly announced it. Mr Anthony went through his typical arm- twisting act and the Liberals displayed their usual dearth of political courage and caved in to the National Party of Australia as it has always done. The proposal was revived again, at least to some extent, in 1980 and the then Liberal Fraser Government backed off, I suppose for the same reason.

The present position, so far as this Government is concerned, is that for this week and the next two weeks an intensive study is being conducted within the three departments which are involved to a considerable extent-or four departments if one counts the Australian Taxation Office as a separate department-the Taxation Office, the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Resources and Energy and the Attorney-General's Department, with a view to producing a paper with figures in it. In the past the absence of specific figures has been a criticism levelled at the Government by the industry although the Government, of course, was caught to some extent in a chicken and egg situation whereby it was not possible to put figures in the paper until other information had been supported by the industry.

Following that three week period, or a little over two weeks from now, that paper will be taken to the States and to the industry for further discussion. Under existing Commonwealth legislation it will be necessary to reach an agreement with Victoria and Western Australia regarding present royalty sharing arrangements and compensation in the form of a percentage share of the rent tax or some other form of compensation to which they have a present legislative entitlement. I think that it ought to be noted for the record that in constitutional terms the payment of any amount to the States from off-shore areas is ex gratia, that is, the States have no constitutional entitlement to any payment from off-shore resources beyond the territorial sea. Under present legislative arrangements they do have an entitlement.

Senator Chaney implied that the industry was monolithic in its opposition to the rent tax proposal. That is not correct. For example, on 23 February, Woodside Petroleum Ltd-I have been given authority by the company to quote this- commenting on the choice between a rent tax or some other form of tax said:

However we also believe that if the choice is between the imposition of a profit based tax and a production based tax the former is to be preferred. Thus a soundly based RRT would be less damaging to the industry than an extension of the levy system which presently applies to 'old oil'. Production based taxes are arbitrary and ignore capacity to pay.

Bridge Oil is reported in the Age on 24 November in similar terms. Perhaps most significant of all are the words of Mr Robert Holmes a Court published in the Business Review Weekly on this subject. In view of the time I will not read both quotations. The first states:
that is, Mr Holmes a Court-

speaks almost glowingly of Resources Minister Senator Peter Walsh's resource rent tax proposal. ''I think it's absolutely clear that a resources rent tax is a very sensible philosophy-a tax based on profits, provided they get the figures right and provided it (the profit) is properly determined.''

Mr Holmes a Court has spoken to me privately in similar terms. Indeed, he said that in principle no rational businessman could oppose this tax. He was, of course, correct, which helps to explain why other business managers in Australia less rational than Mr Holmes a Court sometimes feel threatened by him and perhaps are sometimes threatened by him in a managerial sense. So, the industry is not monolithic on this question. Indeed, there have been some recent-I do not know whether I should say 'reporting', 'rumour mongering' or whatever-approaches from at least one producer that discussions should be held about a levy on new oil rather than a rent tax. Such a proposition has been put forward. In response to that even APEA said in a discussion paper circulated, I think, to all members of the Federal Parliament a few days ago:

However, APEA is strongly opposed to any additional tax on the petroleum production industry and its concern about the impact of the RT would also apply to other forms of tax including an excise on 'new' oil.

In a statement put out at the same time APEA repeatedly made that reference. Just in case there was a view that while there was opposition to a rent tax a levy on new oil would be acceptable or at least preferred. APEA made it perfectly clear that at this time both were equally unacceptable. I should have mentioned that the proposal was discussed at the meeting of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council on 3 February. At that time the State Ministers present agreed when I put the question: 'Would any State Government under any circumstances contemplate or consider increasing the existing State royalties on on-shore production if extremely high producing high profit fields should be discovered? If any State Minister believes that any State Government would ever increase State royalties under those circumstances please say so.' Nobody said so. There was agreement by all the State Ministers that under no circumstances would they increase State royalties above their existing levels either in overt or covert form. I am perhaps a little more sceptical of that assurance now but I think that it ought to be put on record that it was given.

There has been some considerable or at least very important confusion displayed recently by APEA regarding the current policy enforced upon us, of course, by the constitutional limitations of the federal system of applying the rent tax off-shore. APEA has drawn attention to two things. One is that the exploration offset would apply off-shore and not on-shore and the second is that there is a greater national need to explore off-shore than to explore on-shore because the probability of finding large pools of oil off-shore is considered to be greater, and that latter part is correct. But there seems to be a good deal of confusion in APEA'S present thinking in seemingly on the one hand saying that an exploration offset either by way of tax credit or subsidy payable only off-shore will direct, other things being equal, or will concentrate, other things being equal, exploration activity in off-shore areas, which is a reasonable conclusion . This is also what APEA says would be in the national interest, that is, for exploration activity to be concentrated more in off-shore areas. But APEA seems to reach the point of confusion of being opposed to the policy which, according to its own reasoning with other things being equal, would produce the desired result.

I would like to cover many other matters but time does not permit me to do so. There will be-and almost certainly for the reasons Senator Chaney stated-some decline in exploration activity because of the low level of seismic activity in calendar year 1983 and the projected equally low levels of seismic activity in 1984. I stress, however, lest someone attempts to misrepresent this fact and say this is due to the election of the present Government and its policy, that the actual level of seismic activity in the 1983 calendar year was some 30 per cent higher than APEA had predicted at the end of January last year before the Federal election was called. I am not saying that seismic activity increased beyond the expectation because of the election of this Government but it is untrue and it would be completely dishonest to suggest that seismic activity decreased last year because of the election of the present Government.

Nevertheless, there are various reasons why it fell. The decline in seismic activity has implications for the future levels of exploration activity. Probably it will fall in the short term, although it did not decline last year to the extent anticipated. APEA this year is forecasting a significant decline in the number of exploration wells drilled in off-shore areas. It is also forecasting a significant increase in the number of on-shore wells drilled. Again, that has nothing to do with the debate on this matter or the present Government's policy on it.

—The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuing uncertainty being created by the Government's proposal to introduce a resources rent tax.

There is very grave disquiet and uncertainty throughout the community, particularly in the oil industry but also in other resources industries, because of the Government's stated policy on a resources rent tax, because of the stated intention to withdraw, to rescind, the off-shore legislation which provides for sharing between the States and the Commonwealth and, of course, because of the constant repetition of statements by senior Ministers, notably Senator Button, on the possibility of a capital gains tax. Those matters, constantly repeated, create grave uncertainty.

Senator Chaney has made it abundantly clear that for the time being there has been a retreat by the Government on the resources rent tax from coal to oil and then from on-shore oil to off-shore oil. But one can never be certain what this means. One can never be certain whether what the Government is doing for the time being will be making some other raid upon the oil industry in the guise of a resources rent tax or some other kind of levy. The fact is that the Minister, in his speech, was notably silent on the one key thing. He said that he inferred from Senator Chaney that the previous Government had regarded the sole test of its policies on taxing oil the goal of self-sufficiency. Quite clearly, one must regard the goal of self-sufficiency in oil as of paramount consideration for this country. Of course, if one is able to achieve that one also must ascertain how much of the resources one can take back for sharing by the public revenue.

What the Minister did not say was that at the time that the last Labor Government was in power exploration in this country fell to the lowest it has been-something like 25 wells-and that under the Fraser Government's import parity policies, under its nurturing of exploration, it rose to record heights in 1982-83. He also did not say how fragile is this degree of self-sufficiency. To understand this one must understand that in 1977, when self-sufficiency was 67 per cent, it was generally agreed that, unless there were substantial exploration finds, self-sufficiency would decline to 50 per cent by 1985, to 40 per cent by 1990 and to 10 per cent or 20 per cent by the turn of the century. They were perilous figures.

It is a great tribute to the Fraser Government's import parity policy and its nurturing of the industry that it was able to recast those figures more recently and to say that now it is likely that the 67 per cent self-sufficiency will rise in the next two or three years even to something like 77 per cent. One should not be complacent about that, because the prediction is that it will start failing then and will fall very severely from the early 1990s unless exploration is kept at a high point and major discoveries are made. It was extraordinary that a Minister, in debating this matter, did not present the scenario of the degree of self-sufficiency for the next decade or so. Indeed, he ignored the peril of the industry in this regard. The fact is that the industry is in a perilous situation.

The Minister also ignored the fact that, whether or not one taxes new oil at import parity, there is a corporate tax which has a habit of taking 46 per cent of profits and distributing it in the community. So there is such an equity in existence. He also failed to stress that the companies themselves have been very keen and zealous in ploughing back the profits that they have made. From memory, in the last four years, during my own ministry and since, BHP-Esso has ploughed back some $1,200m of profits into exploration, thereby giving the community the prospect of greater self-sufficiency. None of this, of course, was said. He also did not say that the world today is on a knife edge because of the Iran-Iraq war , the dangers of the Strait of Hormuz being closed and the possibility of our having to fall back on our own resources.

He also did not say that the International Energy Agency, of which Australia is a member, has predicted that, even if the Middle East is not in a military crisis, in five, six or seven years from now there is the prospect of an Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries oil crisis, with the demand for oil from the developing countries and the fact that we are using oil at about twice the rate at which we are finding it bringing about a crisis of rising prices. Against that background one needs to ask: Why would one disturb a most successful program? Why would one disturb a program that has taken us from grave danger-under the Whitlam Government's last year, 25 wells and all but one rig gone from Australia-to a great success story?

One difficulty that the Minister has failed to mention is that in his dicussions with industry until now he has talked in general terms. It is only today that we have learnt that there is to be a paper with figures in it. The truth of the matter is that company after company has said to the Minister and to the Government that a resource rental tax would threaten their profitability and their ability to plough their earnings back into exploration and development in this country. It is no good being complacent. Jabiru looks as though it may be interesting, but it has not been proven as yet. In any case, if it is proven, we will need more Fortescues and more Jabirus. I see the Government looking for ways to get around the decision on Fortescue and looking for ways to grab more revenue. This is not just a question, as the Minister put it, of the resources rental tax in his view being a superior tax. In point of fact, in the discussions with industry so far the overwhelming majority of the industry has said that this tax, whatever its theoretical value, is a very dangerous and threatening tax if applied to the industry.

What are we doing with respect to exploration in Australia at the moment? Australia is on a real knife edge as to whether it will go into recovery or go back into recession. Leader after leader in the industry, whether it be Sir Arvi Parbo or Sir James Foots, all indicate that there are dangers to this country. Indeed, Sir James Foots, in an article that I read from the Australian Director of December-January, indicates that he feels that there is real peril for Australia. He says:
What is missing from the economic news so far, is an indication that new investment has begun to increase.
Without some early sign that investment is beginning to pick up I am nervous about the fragility of the recovery.
He goes on to say that it is foreshadowed that:
There is likely to be renewed pressure on interest rates in the second half of 1983/84 . . .

He indicates that it is likely that there will be upward pressures on inflation. So he, like other industry leaders, has painted the picture that if Australia is to emerge into recovery instead of back into recession, we must do nothing to disturb the fragility of that recovery, nothing to increase pressures upon industry, nothing to put up costs. The minerals industry in Australia, with the exception of oil, is in a perilous situation. The coal industry is having mines closed down. The prices for our contracts for iron ore and the volumes of iron ore are falling. All these things mean that the minerals industry and energy industry are prospectively likely to earn less and to employ fewer people in the immediate months and years ahead.

This is the atmosphere in which a government talks about new taxes. Why does the Government not, for example, put people out of their misery on the question of a capital gains tax? Why does it let the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) repeat his view that there ought to be a capital gains tax? The effect of these kinds of things upon industry is threatening. Why does the Government not say whether it will proceed with its attack on the present legislation on off-shore activities, the partnership between the Commonwealth and the States? Why does the present Minister for Resources and Energy remind us gratuitously today that the payments of royalties to the States on oil are ex gratia payments? Why does he do that? It is unnecessary, unless it is in his mind, perhaps, to upset those arrangements.

I cannot understand why in this delicate situation anyone would want to put any new elements into the community. Indeed, what one should be saying is: 'Here we have had a most successful oil exploration and a most successful development.' Can anyone deny with figures that the companies concerned have ploughed back their profits in a very reasonable way, beyond reason in many cases, and developed exploration at an optimum level? Is there any suggestion that they are withholding profits and not developing enough, or that exploration and development are not being financed out of profits in this country? Surely all these things would have needed to have been exposed before one said: 'I shall disturb this situation.' Here was a going concern, recognised throughout the world. The world exploration authorities look at Australia and say: 'Australia is a country of poor prospectivity, of great costs for risks. You have developed , as the International Energy Agency has said, the optimum incentives to industry to explore and to develop.' The IEA says that we have done the optimum in developing our incentives. If that is so and if there is no reflection upon the ploughing back of profits, if there is a success story, if what we are doing is, in the eyes of the international community, the optimum, why would we disturb it? Why would we want to spoil a success story? Why would we want to threaten the minerals and energy industries at a time when they are at a perilous stage?

The sooner the Government answers the questions on the resources rent tax, capital gains tax and off-shore legislation, the sooner we shall understand what it means and what it has in mind. The sooner the Government says whether it will be doing something about another kind of levy on oil, particularly new oil, the sooner we shall be able to evaluate what it is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977 the industry had every right to be shell shocked and thunderstruck at the announcement that came in the Budget from Phillip Lynch, when he said:
The Government is, meanwhile, examining whether the levy should be replaced by a resources tax.

That was on 16 August 1977, a big day for the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, because on the same day, Doug Anthony, as Minister for National Resources, referring to world parity pricing, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about consultation with industry. It should be noted first and foremost that no tax can be proceeded with without that sort of consultation. Senator Peter Walsh has over the past few months gone to great lengths to ensure that it has occurred. Throughout 1983 he made a number of speeches on the resources rent tax and its possible introduction. Furthermore, in December of last year he handed down a discussion paper which has, of course, been widely disseminated throughout the industry and, indeed, throughout the public. In January of this year extensive meetings were held between industry representatives both from the Petroleum Exploration Association and from those individual companies which have been engaged in exploration over some years. Those consultations are still proceeding. What is more, the discussion paper, while it pointed out the reasons for a resources rent tax, also pointed out that there were areas of flexibility which the Government wanted to discuss with industry representatives.

The case for a resources rent tax has been set out in that discussion paper. Without going through it all, I suppose it can be summed up by saying that anyone looking at it in a fair and reasonable manner must concede that the community should receive some compensation for the depletion of irreplaceable national assets and resources and that the community should share in the super profits that can sometimes be earned from these sectors of the resources industry. The profits can result from natural advantages. They can be high grade deposits, easy access to markets, et cetera and, in some cases, such as those referred to by Doug Anthony only a few years ago, profits can result even from government policy. The economic rent accruing from these projects can be enormous. The Labor Party and the Government seek only to tax those profits in excess of that required for an investor to begin and maintain production from a project That was stressed by Ian Viner in that statement that I quoted from at length just a few moments ago.

The current situation is that the States and the Commonwealth are competing in a helter skelter, ad hoc way, each trying to get a cut of this economic rent. At the moment we have royalties, licence fees, freight rates and levies of all kinds on which both tiers of government compete with each other to see how much they can get out of the resources industry. TALK.START.PARA: —The discredited shadow Minister.
