PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Administrative Services spent any money in connection with the proposed assets test program; if so, on what.
(2) From what funds have these moneys been appropriated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes; annual rental commitments totalling $1,836,605 and $485,021 have been entered into to date for the lease of accommodation for the Departments of Social Security and Veterans' Affairs respectively. The moneys were taken from the Department of Administrative Services rental appropriation, Division 130-4-01. In addition, 155 vehicles earmarked for disposal were withheld from auction for use by the Department of Social Security in connection with the assets test program. The vehicles would have realised an estimated $0. 57m at auction and delayed disposal will decrease their sale value. Revenue foregone would have been paid to the transport and storage trust account revenue item 00/24/20.
(3) Appropriation, Division 130-4-01, was authorised in the context of the 1983 -84 Budget. Withholding the 155 vehicles from auction was done with the approval of the Department of Finance.
The Minister for Finance has approved additional rental obligation for urgent accommodation requirements for the pensions assets test.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government believe it has an accurate assessment of the current situation in East Timor resulting from the Indonesian offensive which began in the wake of the visit of the Australian parliamentary delegation in July/August 1983 in the light of the regular briefings the Minister for Defence acknowledged receiving from his Department on developments of interest in Australia's neighbourhood (see answer to Question No. 469, Hansard, 30 November 1983, page 3082).

(2) Is the Government aware of the report broadcast on Radio Australia on 7 December 1983 that Governor Carascalao had called for the restoration of order in the province and asserted that as a result of recent upheavals more than one quarter of the population were in serious need of attention from government agencies; if so, is this report in accordance with the Government's assessment of the situation in East Timor.

(3) Are the restrictions imposed on International Red Cross operations in East Timor by the Indonesian Government, and detailed by the Australian Government in recent months, still in force; if so, has the Government made approaches to the Indonesian Government seeking the immediate lifting of all such restrictions; if not, when will it do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I believe that the Radio Australia report, to which the honourable senator has referred, was drawn from a statement made by Governor Carrascalao in early December 1983. As reported by the Indonesian Government, Mr Carrascalao said that more than 25 per cent of East Timorese still needed serious attention from all Indonesian Government agencies to overcome the difficulties they faced. The Indonesian Government has never denied that East Timor suffers from underdevelopment, as do many areas of Indonesia, and has devoted very significant resources and effort to tackle these problems. On a per capita basis , for example, the development budget for East Timor in recent years has been one of the highest of any Indonesian province. The report of the Australian parliament delegation that visited East Timor in July/August 1983 contains details of the efforts being made by the Indonesian Government to overcome these problems.

(3) As a major contributor to the International Committee of the Red Cross operations in East Timor, the Government is naturally concerned by the restrictions which have been placed on relief activities on the main island and has made its concern known to the Indonesian authorities. The Government hopes that negotiations taking place between the Indonesian authorities and the ICRC will result in the ICRC being able to resume the full range of its operations without delay. While there has never been any doubt that relief operations on the main island have been suspended, the ICRC's family reunion and tracing activities are continuing. Also, the ICRC's food and medical program on Atauro Island has continued uninterrupted.
